column1: 12$Condition: Bipolar Depression$3/28/2019 6:44:04 PM$Reviewer: Bluntlady
column2: 19-24 on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient) $5$5$5$I was prescribed 100mg seroquel by my psychiatrist about a month ago. Make sure you read all possible side effects because there are a lot and some are pretty serious! I cut my dose in half to 50mg because 100mg was way too strong. I have to take it no later than 11pm or i am exhausted the whole next day. So far I have had no side effects from the drug. I take it in combination with Lamictal 300mg and lexapro 20mg in the morning and xanax as needed. This medication has worked great for me. It helps me sleep well and I am noticably more calm. I haven't had to take my xanax nearly as much. It has lowered my anxiety and i have had no severe mood swings or huge breakdowns since i have started it. I have had no weight gain or change in appetite. It is important you have blood work done regularly as it can change cholesterol levels and white blood cell count.

column3: I maxed out at 242 lbs
column4: which lead to me being prediabetic and having to take Metformin.  Determined to lose weight
column5: I had to see a psychiatrist to get off of Seroquel because my primary care physician did not feel comfortable getting me off Seroquel herself.  After a long wait
column6: the psychiatrist tapered me down.  During the tapering process and after I was off of Seroquel
column7: I experienced SEVERE ITCHING ALL OVER MY BODY that lasted about A MONTH.  The itching was everyday at ra don times throughout the day.  The itching from getting off of Seroquel interfered with my ability to concentrate on work or school.  I found that when I was busy
column8: the itching was less severe.  During down time
column9: I would play video games to distract me from the itching
column10: but that stopped working after a while.  Taking showers intensified the itching.  One time I wrapped myself in cold
column11: wet towels which made the itching less intense.  After about 1 month
column12: the terrible itching stopped.  It got off of a Seroquel in September 2017.  It is now April 2018 and I am happy and blessed to say I no longer itch
column13: and I weigh about 184 lb.  I hope this post helps others struggling with weight gain on Seroquel or itching after getting off of Seroquel.

column1:
106$Condition: Schizophrenia$4/25/2015 10:31:33 PM$Reviewer: rick, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient) $5$5$5$I'm sorry to read about the side effects some of you are having.  I've been on Seroquel for years & it works well for me.  Here are some tips for overcoming the most common side effects: if you have weight gain/constipation try using a laxative with prune juice, this should help get your bowels moving and you should be able to lose the weight you have gained; if you have dry mouth or blurred vision, try drinking more fluids and using lubricating eye drops; if you are overly sleepy during the day, try taking Seroquel before you go to bed instead. Also, I would not recommend skipping breakfast - ever.  Eating a good breakfast everyday will help you feel fuller throughout the day & you won't be as tempted to snack on sugary foods.  Most important, don't abruptly stop taking Seroquel without talking to your doctor first.  To do so could have disasterous consequences.  In my case, I would starting vomiting uncontrollably.  Maybe because of a drop in blood sugar?  Don't know.  I hope this helps with Seroquel's side effects.  Be well everybody.

124$Condition: Bipolar Depression$1/8/2015 7:38:52 PM$Reviewer: ThinkingMonkey, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $4$5$5$I was prescribed 300mg of Seroquel several years ago by my psychiatrist for schizophrenia and bipolar disorder. I was also taking about 8 others. Didn't help much and as many of you may have experienced with it, I had a massive weight gain and slept like 20 hours a day. I normally weigh around 200 but was at 260 after about 2 1/2 months(!). I told her I wasn't taking it anymore, it wasn't helping and it had those very severe eating and sleeping side effects. Well, fast forward about 6 years and 2 psychiatrist later and now the new doctor decides Seroquel is a really good idea, 900mg at that, triple what had messed me up so bad earlier. I told her I wasn't taking it but she insisted I at least try it. Lo and behold I felt like a new man and I had no sleeping or eating side effects whatsoever! I couldn't believe it. So I've been taking that dosage for about 3 years now and it works pretty well. The combination of medicine I now take, quite a bit of it, does seem to hinge on my 3mg daily of Ativan though. If I miss a couple of doses it seems to throw EVERYTHING out of whack. None of the other medications seem to work right anymore. So I guess this review is pretty worthless because what I'm saying from personal experience is that Seroquel is horrible and you gain 30 pounds a month and sleep all day and night, but later experience with it proved to work pretty darn good. I would say 'great' but I don't think any medication works 'great', except for Nexium, that is. :)

135$Condition: Manic-Depression$10/10/2014 1:29:02 PM$Reviewer: Wendy
column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient) $4$5$5$"I've been taking Seroquel for 6 months & it has been as vital as a heart pill or any other that helps you maintain a healthy life. There are side-effects
column3: and some are not pleasant but I find that the benefits have greatly outweighed any negatives. In the beginning
column4: I was often tired and had a hard time waking up in the morning
column5: but that has evened out over the months. I also had an initial weight gain of 10 pounds
column6: mostly caused by the Seroquel “munchies” as I call them. And that has also leveled off. You do need to pay closer attention to your diet on it. There is also a strange reaction where you want to move your limbs while you are resting. I found that decreasing my dose some helped with that.

column1: Now the positives: I have never slept better. I used to wake up multiple times during the night and had a difficult time falling to sleep. I now get at least 8 hours of the night and wake up feeling calm and relaxed. And it is a deep
column2: restful sleep. It does not feel artificial or leave me with a medicinal hangover. Sleep has done wonders for my health. I no longer have bad headaches or muscle cramps throughout the day. I rarely have to take ibuprophen (which I used to take almost daily). No more self-medicating with alcohol or alcohol cravings.But the best and most significant difference is that I have finally found my calm! I can be happy
column3: satisfied and content with little things. It's also made me more patient with others. I now know the meaning of peace of mind. It’s no longer me against the world looking for the enemy in everyone I meet. I feel at ease when I wake up and actually enjoy my morning coffee
column4: watching tv
column5: and reading without interruptions from intrusive thoughts.I no longer lash out at my husband or scream at my kids. My compulsions for self-destructive behavior have melted away kind of like a demon leaving my body. I cannot tell you what a huge relief that is. Everything is lighter without the weight of your own guilt and shame. It gave me my life back"

column1: 136$Condition: Additional Medications to Treat Depression$9/17/2014 5:01:15 PM$Reviewer: Jijaxs2
column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $5$3$5$"#1 If you are worried about your weight
column3: DON'T TAKE SEROQUEL. I was a 5'1"" 115# female. My weight is very important to me. I've worked out the majority of my life. But when I ended up in a hospital for suicidal thoughts
column4: I really didn't even care
column5: think or wonder what this med would do to me. It made me feel better. I worked up to 300mg in a short time (May-September). I have gained enough weight (30 pounds) to make it impossible for me to fit into my clothes. I thought I'll just stop taking it. After 2 nights very bad withdrawal symptoms. I am still going to get off this med but I'm going to wean myself off. I am also a LUPUS patient. I had no idea that this med was making my LUPUS symptoms worse. I realized during those 2 days I did not take the medication. My lupus symptoms decreased.  This CANNOT BE A GOOD MEDICATION. IT LITERALLY MADE ME SUFFER SO MUCH MORE WITH MY LUPUS!! I do not care if my doctor approves or not
column6: I will NOT continue this med
column7: but I will be more careful taking myself off of it."

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient) $5$5$4$I was prescribed this medication for insomnia and anxiety and I take a very low dose.  It is a godsend!  Taking just one of the lowest dosage pills allows my brain to calm down and I fall asleep within 30 minutes.  I feel I am getting much more effective REM sleep but it does cause me to dream more (or at least dream more vividly and remember my dreams.)  One of the nicest things about using Seroquel for sleep is that I am not left with a groggy or tired feeling the next morning.  I wake up fully rested and ready to tackle the day.  I'd highly recommend this drug in a low dose to others who suffer from a brain that won't shut off and allow you to sleep or stay asleep.

189$Condition: Other$1/27/2014 4:17:36 AM$Reviewer: MissingMyDad, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Caregiver) $1$1$1$Long story short
column2: this poison killed my Father. My Dad fell and broke his hip on Christmas Eve 2010
column3: and died on June 4th
column4: 2011. While he was 83 at the time of his death
column5: he was living alone
column6: caring for himself
column7: and handling all his own affairs. NEVER did he ever exhibit any symptoms of dementia or Alzheimer's. (Something my Mother ultimately died of)

column1: During the surgery for the broken hip
column2: something happened to him and mentally
column3: he was never the same. Things progressed rapidly and more than one ""doctor"" gave him Seroquel because
column4: and I quote ""It's great for patients with dementia like symptoms"".

column1: It wasn't until after he passed away that I found out the drug explicitly states ""NOT to be given to patients with dementia like symptoms"". It seems this is a VERY common practice with providers.
If you read up on the list of potential side effects Seroquel bestows upon it's victims
column2: while my Father didn't have all of them
column3: every symptom he had
column4: was one that Seroquel listed. (And NONE of them were problems he had prior to starting on it.)

column1: Do yourself a favor and stay away from this poison. At the very least
column2: NEVER let some quack prescribe it for your elderly parents.

column1: I certainly wish I hadn't.  "

column2: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient) $4$1$5$Be very careful with this drug. I was prescribed it for anxiety-based insomnia and it worked well for me for about six years. However
column3: in my sixth year I started getting symptoms of tardive dyskinesia (involuntary and violent shaking of left arm
column4: dizziness
column5: falling over). Research into tardive dyskinesia confirmed links to using seroquel -- and if not remedied
column6: it can become permanent. My doctor had me in to test for brain tumors
column7: Meniere's disease
column8: we had no idea why I kept falling over and my arm would shake so violently. We decided to see if was the drug. Sure enough
column9: once I stopped taking seroquel
column10: all my symptoms vanished. It's a fantastic drug to counter depression and insomnia
column11: but watch very very carefully for any involuntary body movements. If you see that happening
column12: discontinue the drug asap
column13: lest it becomes a permanent condition.

236$Condition: Bipolar Depression$9/6/2013 11:23:51 PM$Reviewer: DannyC., 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $4$4$5$I've only been on Seroquel for about 4 months.  I take 200 mg before bed and sleep pretty well. At first
column2: I did have some vivid and anxious dreams but that tapered off after time.  If I still have trouble staying asleep I can take .5 mg Xanax and the combination usually puts me in a restful sleep.  No hangover effect for me.  No ill effects at all
column3: really.  I also take 200 mg Lamictal along with 150 mg Wellbutrin  and most days about .5 mg of Adderall in the morning.  Then another 100 Lamictal at night.  After decades of ""spinning the wheel of antidepressants""
column4: this combo finally has yielded a very positive result.  No more highs and lows.  A great deal more focus
column5: energy
column6: concentration and drive.  Helped me end my love affair with alcohol too...no serious anxiety or worries to hide from. Everything seems a lot less complicated and easier to deal with.  It's not that my life is without problems
column7: it's just a lot easier to assess
column8: address
column9: and handle things.  I have actually lost weight probably due to the Adderall.  As far as my dosage
column10: I could keep adjusting up or down on any of these
column11: but I'm pretty happy with what I've got going now...don't want to upset the apple cart here. Best I've felt since I was a kid
column12: it's about time.  I hope it lasts!"

column1: 260$Condition: Other$6/27/2013 5:51:37 PM$Reviewer: Jayne
column2: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient) $4$1$5$This is just a warning to others taking Seroquel as a sleep aid based on my own experiences with it: I took Seroquel for 6 years to battle insomnia. It was wonderful
column3: I never had to increase the dosage
column4: and I got a sound night's sleep. After about the fourth year
column5: I started to develop severe parkinson-like symptoms where my left arm would start involuntarily and violently shaking and my hand would curl up and palsy. If I was holding something
column6: I'd drop it. I had no control over my arm and hand. Severe dizzy spells accompanied these random and uncontrollable spasms
column7: many times ending with me falling over. I went to three neurologists
column8: had a catscan for a brain tumor
column9: and all came back negative. My doctor suggested taking me off the seroquel to see if it helped. Within a month
column10: my symptoms had vanished. Be very very careful about using this drug for longterm sleep issues. My quality of life plummeted when we could not discern what was causing my symptoms and it was only after stopping seroquel that my health issues stopped.

column1: 276$Condition: Bipolar Depression$5/19/2013 10:23:11 PM$Reviewer: DeplinEvangelist
column2: 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $1$1$1$"For me
column3: this med was a disaster.  It was prescribed for me initially by a pill pushing shrink who made a snap judgement that I was bipolar II after my wife filed for divorce and I asked for help.  I had been on and off anti-depressants for years
column4: usually after failed relationships.  It made things worse
column5: not better
column6: and I ended up in and out of the psych ward six times over the next three years
column7: and each time they increased the dose
column8: finally to  a staggering 900 mg per day
column9: also prescribing high doses of Lamictal
column10: Abilify
column11: Effexor and Clonazepam
column12: at  which point I became a zombie and was unable to function for nearly two years.  I also gained the standard 80 lbs.  I'm my experience this drug and the others represent all that is wrong with ""modern"" psychiatry; blindly throwing questionable meds at the problem without an understanding of the underlying brain chemistry.  My salvation from this nightmare came when I got fed up and started seeing a psychiatrist who had the reputation as being one of the best in the business in a large West Coast city.  She carefully listened to my symptoms
column13: my story
column14: and after a few sessions had me tested for the MTHFR genetic mutation
column15: which occurs in various forms in approximately 10% of the population.  Turns out I had two of the mutations which keep the body from processing folic acid
column16: a common vitamin found in many foods
column18: which is needed to balance the common mood regulators
column21: which I am sure many of you know about if you are on this website.  Her solution was to put me on Deplin
column22: a medicinal food ( not a drug!) and wean me off Seroquel and the other drugs
column23: which she felt were either totally useless or in the case of Seroquel did more harm than good.  Within a month I started feeling much better and after four months I was weaned off all of the meds
column24: completely symptom free  This is my story only
column25: but beware Astra Zeneca and the pill pushing incompetent shrinks."

column1: 309$Condition: Bipolar Depression$1/28/2013 9:05:04 AM$Reviewer: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient) $1$1$1$I took Seroquel for 9 months & I HATED it.  I worked up to 300mg.  I took the medication at night & it would knock me out for 10 – 12 hours straight.  I gave it a couple months to see if the side effects would lessen.  They didn’t.  So we cut my dosage in half down to 150mg.  I still slept a lot & I could not get moving the next day.  I kept taking the meds thinking things would level out over the next few months.  They didn’t.  The medication did not help my depression at all & on top of that my body felt so drugged.  I was so weak that I could barely take care of every day household chores.  I almost never left my house because I always felt so bad both emotionally & physically.  We cut my dosage down again & a couple months later I still felt horrible.  I WAS A PRISONER IN MY OWN BODY!!  I read that other people gained weight on this medication.  I actually LOST weight.  I have always been thin but while on this medication I started to look like a walking skeleton.  I live alone & I was too weak & tried to even get up to cook.  I was only eating one small meal a day.  It was quite scary watching myself literally withering away.  I finally asked my doctor to get me off Seroquel.  She prescribed Citalopram (generic for Lexapro) and after just two weeks I am starting to feel better & I am eating better also.  I regret wasting almost a year of my life on Seroquel.  I should have gotten off of it sooner.  Live & learn.

column1: 335$Condition: Bipolar Depression$11/14/2012 7:09:22 PM$Reviewer: 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient) $2$1$4$Warning: I experienced Neuroleptic Toxicity and Extrapyramidal Symptoms.  I have been on this medication for sevearal years.  Was at 300 mg. daily along with Klonopin
column2: Wellbutrin
column3: Mirapex (for RLS) and Lamictal.  Then Lithium was added and I developed neurological symtoms so severe that at first the neurologist thought it was a stroke. Developed hypothyroidism (as I had before on Lithium). Physical Therapy
column4: use of cane
column5: inability to drive
column6: poor speech
column7: reduced cognitive skills were very scary.  Symptoms in remission after 3 months.  Then bouts of akathesia (made my legs feel like the nerves were on the outside
column8: feel you can't sit or stand
column9: severe restlessnes). Weight gain was horrible
column10: and increased as dosage increased. 40 ponds in the last year. Hungry all the time. I was just taken off of the drug two weeks ago and I cannot believe the change in metabolism.  Yes
column11: I have more difficulty sleeping (switched to Trazadone) and racing thoughts are back
column12: but I am determined to deal with those holistically and with DBT. I cannot live in fear of neurological symptoms. Neuroleptic Toxicity and Extrapyramidal Symptoms are no joke. In my experience
column13: it is not worth taking and never in combination with Lithium.

365$Condition: Bipolar Depression$9/11/2012 9:05:35 PM$Reviewer: APB, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient) $2$1$3$The effects I was were experiencing were hard to describe, but I was simply put, not myself. I felt innebriated and out of focus. I did not feel safe to drive. I had distinct memory loss and my temper was shorter than normal. And the mood swings were not resolved at all. I stopped taking seroquel and switched to Prozac to address the moodswings. My OBGYN is quite sure I was misdiagnosed and suffer from PMDD as opossed to bipolar II. I have been taking Prozac for 2 months and feel like I have my life back. Another note worth mentioning is that I've never had a weight problem, and at age 40 have been 125-132 since age 20. Within a month of taking seroquel I had gained 15 pounds. It was a very strange experience. Be advised that seroquel is a very serious, mind-altering drug. It felt very dangerous and unnecessary for me, but again, perhaps it was due to a misdiagnosis.

column2: 3-6 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Caregiver) $4$5$3$"My 5yr old son has numerous struggles including insomnia

column1: 397$Condition: Additional Medications to Treat Depression$5/28/2012 3:12:06 PM$Reviewer: tresvick
column2: 55-64 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient) $1$1$5$"This is a horrible medicine and I believe it should only be used as a last-ditch effort. At first it was a medication for severe psychotic disorders. Now it seems to be used as a catch-all for any type of depression or

column1: behavior problems. Even a small dosage can have lasting side effects
column2: especially uncontrolled body movements and tics in different parts of your body that may or may not go away. My first experience with it caused my neck to move involuntarily in stiff movements. My next doctor ignored my reaction and gave me a low dosage of this drug. The first night after taking it
column3: I couldn't walk straight; the second night my knee started to click when I walked; the third night my ankles started to click; the last night my neck started to crick or pop every time I moved it. That was the last night I took it and it took a year for my neck to stop clicking when I moved it. Even after that
column4: my doctor ordered refills for me. I didn't take them and stopped seeing that doctor. I think you really need to be careful and if a medication is causing you unusual reactions
column5: stop taking it and tell your doctor. If he won't listen
column6: stop taking the medication and find another doctor who will listen to you and work with you to fing a medication that will help you instead of turning a psychotic medication for a non-psychotic condition."

column2: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient) $4$4$2$"What I've learned from 8+ years of taking Seroquel:

column1: 1. Gaining weight was a problem in the past
column2: however it is not now. Exercising
column3: eating lousy (yes
column4: lousy)
column5: and taking supplements to help with the vitamin deficiencies have helped me over the years. My definition of eating lousy is: Ice Cream with lots of peanuts on top. At least once a day. I use protein shakes and mix in good things to make up for the loss of the most vital nutriants. I don't eat junk food
column6: or drink soda. I drink iced tea and water. I've found that no calorie sweetners increase my anxiety. To help with constipation
column7: I take an Acidopholus based supplement. Btw
column8: I am NOT endorsing my methods of eating!

column1: 2. Seroquel makes me ""eat walk"". Definition: 1/2-3/4 hour after taking my Seroquel
column2: I get hungry
column3: so I head for the kitchen and get something to eat. Unfortunately
column4: eating kicks in my Seroquel
column5: causing me to stumble about in the kitchen
column6: and frequently falling. I have slept quite a few nights on the kitchen floor due to this. A friend of mine who witnessed this
column7: told me I was like a kid who didn't want to go to bed at night.

column1: My answer to this has been to take a snack with me to bed. Because of this
column2: I have many nightgowns with chocolate stains on them!

column1: A Seroquel friend of mine was the one who asked me if I had noticed that Seroquel kicks it in much more quickly after eating.
3. Know your dose. If you're on the hypomanic side of bp
column2: talk to your pdoc if adjusting the dosage is right for you. I have found that Seroquel does not help with my depression
column3: so my pdoc adjusts my dosage accordingly. I am atypical
column4: so my dosage needs are normally higher than most others.

column1: 4. Don't give up the benefits of Seroquel because of the potential weight gain. Most of us know that finding a med that finally works can be really tough
column2: and side effects come along with the package. There are so many different ways to stay active and get rid of any weight gain you might come across.

column1: If I can do make it
column2: You can too!"

448$Condition: Bipolar I Disorder with Most Recent Episode Mixed$2/22/2012 3:11:55 AM$Reviewer: Jenntonic1, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $5$5$5$I attempted suicide 2 months ago & landed in the hospital. (Honestly it was a blessing in disguise.) I had bouts of mania & depression on & off for over 18yrs untreated. At times I thought that there was nothing wrong with me & everyone else was the problem. During my 20's I experienced feelings of being immortal
column2: invincible & on top of the world. I became a risk taker. All of these actions felt normal to me. I drank alcohol
column3: used drugs
column4: spent money without a care & later have buyers remorse or overwhelming feelings of guilt. Several times a year I would feel depressed & have thoughts of suicide but honestly never thought I would actually attempt it. Deep down I knew there was some type of chemical imbalance with the ups & down. Later I realized my actions greatly affected those around me. When I would start to feel mania or ""normal""
column5: I would forget about needing help & think everything was ok. Never once did I consider that I may have a mental illness. When I turned 30
column6: I started having lower back pain that is now chronic. 3 years ago I also found out that I have arthritis and fibromyalgia & that these too are chronic. I tried a few antidepressants & pain management
column7: none that really worked. I withdrew from life
column8: stayed in bed & isolated myself
column9: I became agitated
column10: anxious & my stress level was through the roof. My relationship of 11 years became rocky & my partner left. Now
column11: at 38yrs everything finally crashed together. So I tried to take my life.(I'm happy that didn't work out!) I was soon diagnosed with Bipolar I disorder during my hospital stay. My psychiatrist started me on a better pain regimen that works plus a low dose of Seroquel 50mg then up to only 100mg. My pain
column12: mood & depression are more manageable & my relationship is back. I've combined that with therapy & proper rest. I'm back in my life and doing what I need to stay balanced. I have much work to do & may need to up my dose later. It's amazing how this med has evened me enough to enjoy life again."

column4: it sometimes impacts my ability to be on my ""A"" game because I am tired.  It also makes me a little irritable--I'm not sure if the trade-off is worth it (e.g.
column5: the medication and its side effects in lieu of suffering from bipolar).  Unfortunately
column6: most psychotropic drugs have a downer effect and this one is no different.  It seems my experience is on par with most other people's.  Two things I know for sure

column9: this medication (at least in Illinois) can get you a DUI if you are under its influence and driving.  Be aware!"

497$Condition: Other$12/9/2011 11:43:10 PM$Reviewer: Berkley2580, 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient) $5$4$5$I take this medication for insomnia, over the past few years I have tried numerous medications and this is the only thing that has ever worked for me.  Unlike other medications after taking this for a while I do not need to increase my dosage... In fact I can actually decrease my dosage. Unlike other reviews this medication does not make me gain weight, the only negative side effect is being sleepy when I first wake up (however, this is the same affect ambien or other sleep aids will have). If you are experiencing weight gain or concerned about weight gain I would suggest talking to your doctor to make sure your dosage is right. A little goes a long way with this drug. I take 25 mg every night, sometimes less if I am already feeling tired.

500$Condition: Other$12/8/2011 1:12:05 AM$Reviewer: Luna, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient) $5$4$4$I have been taking this for sleep for about 12 years and in different dosages. Now I am on Seroqel CR and having *some* problems adjusting. Everyone is different but 50 mgs is very high to me and with the Seroquel CR I kind of feel like a zombie in the morning; a bit agitated at night. Prob 'cuz I have tried to cut this in half and take it: Bad idea! Cutting it made me feel sick. Also I have diareeha and trouble driving. **NOTE: I have only been on CR for three weeks: The reg dose I used to take (25mgs) was fine and helped me sleep without anxiety--yet had diareeha only on occasion...when I ate right before bed. If you do feel hungry just eat some crackers or something not anything big--that is the key to not gaining a lot of weight.:) And exercise/eat right..I know *reader eye roll*but it helps. I wish the CR of Seroquel came in 25mg! I would advise eating early if you can and take it WHEN YOU ARE IN BED/READY TO SLEEP.
If you skip a dose and can't sleep that's why 'cuz you may have restlessness from not taking it. Take it the next night;try to keep the timing the same.
Don't watch anything ""weird"" on TV or you can have nightmares- sometimes I just read.
Good Luck everyone and sweet dreams!"
501$Condition: Bipolar I Disorder with Most Recent Episode Mixed$12/6/2011 3:54:48 PM$Reviewer: eternity26
column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient) $5$5$5$"I have been on Seroquel for I believe 8 years now. IT IS A WONDER DRUG!!!! Yes I too gained weight in the first month. It was worth it to me to be ""sane"" again!!! I have always suffered from what I thought was severe mania and I would work with my doctor and he let me adjust my meds accordingly. I don't drink alcohol OR do drugs that is a huge factor in the seroquel working for me! I was on very  high dose's of seroquel It was my decision not my doctors because of the delusions prior to me taking seroquel were very scary to me! It was like I was trapped in another world and I wasn't having fun! I  was on an average 300 mil of seroquel every night but at some points 600mil.  I was at the same job for 8 years and didn't even know they (my co workers) were stressing me out to the point I had to take such high doses. Well I was fired from that job and 3 months later I'm down to 100 mill a night and I have NEVER been happier! I'm a hair dresser and my clients all can tell I'm a different person!!! I've started losing weight 10 pounds since my dosages have changed. (  I lowered my meds  VERY SLOWLY
column3: otherwise you could spiral into depression) It really helps if you know the signs of your symptons. Which I was in denial because I was always happy (or so I thought) I didn't agree with the depression symptoms the internet told me I was having. But I now know it was the truth. I would have lowered my meds ALOT SOONER
column4: IF I realized I wasn't as manic as I thought. I'm not sure if anyone else read before about when depressed we stop taking showers
column5: Well I was only taking showers once a week
column6: for time sakes or I'd be late for work! No one ever knew! I didn't smell or try to cover it up with perfume! Of course I never went to the gym so I was never sweaty and all gross! Well I hoped this has helped someone
column7: if you'd like to contact me I'm at [email protected]'m Kat BTW. Good luck and GOD BLESS"

504$Condition: Additional Medications to Treat Depression$12/5/2011 1:20:07 PM$Reviewer: schtinky, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient) $1$1$1$WARNING:  Do not let your doctor talk you into taking this medicine while you are on any anxiety medication like xanax or ativan.  I had a SEVERE and scary reaction to the combination of Serequel and Ativan - I blacked out in a fugue and had a psychotic episode.  I remember nothing of it but both my mother and husband witnessed abnormal behavior such as flushing all my medication, putting turkey salad in a bowl and pouring milk on it like cereal, and thinking my socks were a chocolate bar.  This side effect isn't included in the 'interactions' portion but there is a caution regarding use of anxiety medication.  Seroquel is DANGEROUS.  I could have seriously injured myself, and its frightening to not remember a thing you did or said while others tell you that you were acting psychotic.  Ask for another medication such as risperidone that isn't as dangerous as Seroquel.

column1: 531$Condition: Other$10/22/2011 8:36:08 PM$Reviewer: ambrakay
column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient) $1$1$4$Immediately after the removal of my brain tumor and my temporal lobe resection
column3: I was suffering from major depressive disorder with having my amygdala removed
column4: not to mention 30% of my brain.  A psychiatrist
column5: not allowing me to so much as explain that I'd had brain surgery 6 weeks prior
column6: within less than a minute declared I was bipolar and told me to stop my Lexapro (for generalized anxiety disorder) cold turkey and start taking Seroquel.  He started me on 50 mgs with the intent of getting me up to 300.  By the 3rd week
column7: when I was up to 150 mgs
column8: I wanted to die.  I couldn't stop crying and I slept for at least 13 hours a night.  I was soooo miserable.  Then my seizures came back with a vengeance.  I called my neuro and he told me anyone with epilepsy is not to take any ana-antipsychotics.  I stopped Seroquel immediately and weaned back onto my Lexapro and saw a psychiatrist who works specifically with epilepsya patients who put me on .5 mgs Risperdal for 3 mos as a booster to my Lexapro to get me through the hump of post surgical depression.  That did the trick :-)  By the way
column9: I've since seen 2 other psychiatrists who have confirmed that I do not have depression
column10: nor am I bipolar.

It knocked me out and took a while to adjust to. I suppose it has helped with my mania (I seem to only have them when I drink-- not a good idea). Overall I am able to focus, process, and make responsible decisions now. The draw back is the weight gain- which just in the last six months has become noticeable and embarrassing. That alone makes me dislike my self image- but who wouldn't. The worst part for me is knowing that I can never come off of this drug because I ran out several months ago and experienced awful withdrawals. I was so sick and my insides hurt. I felt like I was dying. I never want to experience that again ever. It was terrible. As long as I take the drug daily and do not drink I am fine. I'll have to do something about this 20+ pounds on my tiny frame though. My clothes don't fit! Just do everything you can to not go through the withdrawals. And consider this a warning- you might get stuck taking this forever. Bonus- AZ&Me has patient plans and financial assistance to those who qualify.

column1: 583$Condition: Bipolar Depression$8/24/2011 11:12:08 AM$Reviewer: Crash85
column2: 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $5$5$5$When I was first diagnosed as Bi-Polar approx. 10 years ago
column3: I was put on an SSRI. The SSRI had bad side effects
column4: and I stopped taking. I have tried several different SSRI Anti-Depressants during this 10 year span. Approx. 3 years ago I ended up in a Mental Health Facility
column5: and while in there I saw a psychiatrist. After an assessment the Doctor again diagnosed me as Bi-polar with an added diagnosis of Severe Anxiety w/Panic Attacks
column6: and again tried another SSRI that was fairly new to me at the time called Celexa. I took it for about a month or so until the same side effects I have always had with SSRIs began. So I went to my new doctor and explained this to him. He then prescribed me Seroquel to try as an alternative to an SSRI
column7: at first at a low dosage
column8: than higher as I needed it. Not only did it NOT cause the same unwanted side effects as the SSRIs did
column9: it eased my conditions very well and proved to be extremely effective. It has successfully countered my Bi-Polar Disorder for the last 3 or so years. It also aides with the Severe Anxiety & Panic Attacks (along with Clonazepam). Lastly
column10: I have also been diagnosed as an Insomniac and again Seroquel alone has also conquered that diagnosis as well. All in all
column11: while this medicine is expensive due to the lack of generics (patent hasn't expired) it is well worth the money as I have had multiple disabling problems managed with the use of this one drug. The price of the medication can be adjusted with insurance
column12: and/or a financial plan with the Drug Company themselves who offer RX Discounts

After 2 yrs of feeling like a depressed, fat, anesthised, drugged out, zombie, I weaned myself off this medicine. It's been over 3 years and have I never felt better. I lost 60 pounds in the first 6 months and started living life again. I was misdiagnosed in my early 20's as manic-depressive and was prescribed every type of psych drug a person can take. I found a new psych who listened and helped me gradually wean off all of the meds. I no longer take any psych meds at all. I finally feel like my self again! Seroquel caused me to gain a lot of weight, dried out my nose, gave me headaches, caused severe dry mouth and tooth decay, restless leg syndrome, muscle and tendon problems, confusion, grogginess, craved sweets, rebound insomnia, agitation, irritability, clumsiness, blurred vision, racing heart beat, and a overall decline in my health.

621$Condition: Bipolar Depression$6/29/2011 4:56:49 AM$Reviewer: 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $2$1$4$Seroquel was expensive and no fun at all.  After taking my dose, I would be in between sleep and wakefulness.  I would not be able to sleep, but would be very drowsy and yet restless.  It was a very uncomfortable feeling.  I would lie down and not be able to get comfortable.  The uncomfortable feeling occurred whether I took Seroquel in the morning or at night.  I kept taking it anyway.  I can't say how much it helped and how much was the natural course of my bipolar disorder.  But I would not take it again if I had the choice (and fortunately nobody's asking me to.)  Maybe it will work for you, but not for me.  I haven't taken it in years.  Now I'm on a generic version of Lamictal and a generic version of Risperdal.  Risperdal used to have a similar effect on me, but it doesn't anymore.  Maybe it was my drinking that caused the unpleasant side effects.  Who knows why these drugs work this way?  I sure don't.  But I'm much better without drinking.  I recommend it (quitting drinking).

666$Condition: Other$4/24/2011 3:20:14 PM$Reviewer: copslstopya, 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months$1$1$1$Read the insert. This medication slowly kills you if you don't die because of its similar action to alcohol. It was just like being drunk except no euphoria. I was expelled from public venues while on this drug because the consensus was that I ""was drunk or on drugs"". I was refused service at fast food and told the 'cops have been called"" because I was staggering and slurring speech. I cut and bruised myself countless times without knowing how.  I tripped and fell because I could not lift my toes when walking. All this as a man in his prime.   Being compelled to be on this drug because to refuse would have resulted in depot injections of an even more damaging and debilitating drug still has me exasperated more than a decade later. I was subjected to an injustice by being compelled to eat this poison and an insult for being billed for  the cost of the pills.  Every time I see an auto accident I wonder if this drug or some other psych med is involved.
This chemical should be banned and the knowledge of it be allowed to expire from human consciousness.

It effects healthy and not so healthy persons  and mammals in an identical fashion.  It has no core effect.  It is a confusing blend of side effects and produces extreme paradoxical reactions within only a few hours in some individuals.
It is carcinogenic and how a doctor sworn to ""do no harm"" could consider it for inclusion in their practice baffles me."

747$Condition: Other$1/18/2011 8:08:14 PM$Reviewer: Danielle, 13-18 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient) $5$5$5$i was prescribed seroquel to help alleviate the symptoms of marijuana withdrawal. i was a chronic smoker for three years and became both mentally and physically dependent. i was trying to self medicate, but it only made my bipolar and anxiety disorders worse. my psychiatrist prescribed 50mg of seroquel to combat the insomnia, loss of appetite, anxiety, depression and racing thoughts that accompanied my withdrawal. plus, it gives you a similar feeling of being high. i was told to take 25mg at night before going to sleep and 50mg if i have an anxiety attack. i did gain a considerable amount of weight...but that's nothing compared to being sober and getting control of my life. i am tapering off of seroquel right now because i feel that i don't need it anymore. i'm currently cutting the pill in fourths, so i take 12.5mg every night. overall, this medication felt like a godsend. many people cannot handle the effects of seroquel, but i would highly recommend that if you're struggling with a drug addiction to seek help from a medical professional and ask about seroquel. it will ease withdrawal symptoms considerably.

882$Condition: Additional Medications to Treat Depression$8/17/2010 7:49:39 PM$Reviewer: 65-74 on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $5$3$5$I was prescribed Seroquel to add to Effexor and Buscar. After eight days, I suffered uncontrollable shaking, and I couldn't walk. I took an ambulance to the hospital, where I was given tests, including ultrasounds, a heart cath, and an MRI. It was all ok. I also have occasional A Fib, and my heart was also in A Fib. After three days, the shaking was gone, the A Fib was gone, and I returned home. The doctors at the Hospital took me off the Buspar. That was three weeks ago. I have had several A Fib incidents, and have been in and out of rhythm. I have occasional weakness and dizziness. But I have always had a sleep problem, but it has allowed me to sleep. I don't know if I should report the weakness to my doctor. The A Fib happens everytime I get the slightest bit upset or bothered. Before this period, I suffered A Fib only three times in four years. It has now happened four times in the past week. I am 74 years old.

column8: She is in NO way a ""zombie"" at any time throughout the day.She takes 50mg at noon & 100 mg at bedtime (8pm)along with Concerta ER 36 mg(in the am for ADHD).

column2: but for our granddaughter & for us
column3: Seroquel

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient) $5$1$5$"I was first given a prescription for this drug back in 2001 or 2002 (sadly my memory is very foggy and can't quite remember exactly). column1: Please do not start taking this medicine do whatever it takes to never take this drug it will ruin your life. I once was intelligent but now I have so much brain fog that I can barely spell or remember simple words. Not too mention dizziness

936$Condition: Bipolar Depression$7/3/2010 7:08:02 AM$Reviewer: Riga, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $4$2$4$Seroquel worked wonders once when I was experiencing a consistent feeling of unreality for days. The very next day I began to feel at home in the world, not anxious or depressed.  However, as soon as the drug started to take effect (I took it at night), I would be so dizzy I couldn't walk without holding on to furniture.  I would fall asleep anywhere--on the floor of the closet while looking for something in a box, on the floor on my exercise mat, standing up in the kitchen drinking a cup of coffee.  I'd wake up when the coffee spilled or I started to fall (if I was standing up), but I had a horrible experience waking up on the floor of the closet covered in clothing that had fallen on top of me, not being able to remember where I might be--it was pitch black, I was covered in something--was I in hell?  I didn't think I was dead but I was terrified until I crawled out of the closet and realized I was in my bedroom.  My husband would find me sleeping on the floor all over the house.  So, I went down on the dose. Still had side effects (less though)and it didn't work as a sleeping pill for me. Right now I'm trying not to take it until I need it again.  It is a VERY effective drug but side effects are surreal.
937$Condition: Other$6/30/2010 2:26:44 PM$Reviewer: Southern Lady, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $4$4$4$I started taking Seroquel four year ago to treat severe insomnia.  I started taking 350 mg.  After two months of hardly any sleep and feeling ""homocidal""
column2: this drug finally got me the sleep I needed.  However
column3: as with others who have written
column4: I would get the ""munchies"" within 1/2 hour of taking it and gained weight.  I also feel like a zombie in the mornings unless I get about 10 hours of sleep.  Over time
column5: I whittled down the amount of dosage little by little.  I am now taking somewhere between 35-38 or so mg. (I cut the pills with a pill cutter).  This is the least I can use without disrupting my sleep. I still have trouble getting up early (less than 8 hours) in the morning.  The way I resolve the ""feeding frenzy""  I take the Seroquel within 10 minutes of going to bed before the ""munchies"" kick in.  I eventually want to get off the drug all together because you know the damage presdcription drugs can do to the kidneys. ""less is more"" in this case
column6: which is why I reduced the amount of dosage.  For those using Seroquel just for insomnia
column7: experiment with dosage reduction and go to bed directly after taking it to avoid overeating/raiding the fridge and gorging (yes....I did it and gained 25 pounds.....trying to work it off)."

column1: 979$Condition: Bipolar I Disorder with Most Recent Episode Mixed$5/17/2010 3:36:41 PM$Reviewer: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $5$4$4$Have been on Lamictal about 8 years
column2: added Seroquel about 2 years ago and have never been more stable emotionally--I have a good job and good relationships and I haven't had an episode in 2 years since I've been on it--and bipolar does not control me anymore.  Good combo of drugs.  However
column3: Seroquel's side effects are considerable.  They are manageable
column4: but you have to put in some effort--get blood tests to check your thyroid and cholesterol and fats
column5: eat really healthy and work out or you will gain weight
column6: schedule your days so you can always get 9-10 hours of sleep even if you have to go to bed by 8pm.  The heart palpitations don't hit me if I stay in bed once I take it--the palpitations only show up if I try to fight through the drowsiness to move around
column7: so I just plan to be in bed for 10 hours.  It's a question of what you're willing to put up with to be stable emotionally.  Bipolar made my life hell
column8: as long as I could remember
column9: and for the first time
column10: I've been stable for more than a few weeks at a time.  2 good years and counting.

column1: 990$Condition: Other$5/11/2010 2:04:10 AM$Reviewer: PurplePassion
column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient) $4$4$2$"I have suffered from depression my entire life. A decade ago
column3: I was involved in a very traumatic experience that sent me into a downward spiral. I was diagnosed with acute clinical depression with PTSD and Anxiety. After trying every single anti-depressant out there with no improvement and some worsening the conditions
column4: I finally got on Pristiq. It helped a lot but I still suffered from mood swings occasionally and insomnia every night. My dr prescribed Seroquel. I am much more calm. I was on 300mg but have gone down to 200mg. I take it at night. At first
column5: it knocked me out almost immediately and I slept through the night. After being on it for over a year
column6: it's not as effective at helping me fall asleep but once I am asleep
column7: I stay asleep.

column1: However
column2: there is a HUGE side effect that I've suffered greatly from and that is weight gain. I've gained 45lbs since being on it. When I would take it
column3: I would develop the munchies identical to those you get when you're under the influence of alcohol or marijuana. The desire for food is too hard for me to fight. However
column4: I am a food addict so I am sure this plays a lot into my problem with not being able to control myself when I get the ""hungries"" this drug causes. Other than that
column5: I've had no other side effects besides daytime sleepiness but it usually wears off once I get going. As well as this drug has worked for me
column6: I now have diabetes and am morbidly obese so I plan on switching the drugs around. I recommend this drug to anyone who is NOT a food addict and needs a boost to their antidepressant and help sleeping at night. Try to stay at the lowest effective dose you can to minimize side effects. Wish me luck! I am going to switch to abilify and try ambien or lunesta again
column7: even though they haven't been that helpful in the past.  "

column1: 991$Condition: Manic-Depression$5/10/2010 12:36:13 PM$Reviewer: dntsaynuthn

column4: but when I when to my psychiatrist I asked to have my weight taken and I had gained 32 lbs in less than 3 months!  I was on Seroquel and then tried Seroquel XR to try to relieve the weight gain but unfortunately I had to switch medications because the weight gain was a steady gain.  I would monitor your weight closely while on this medication.

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $2$1$3$"Seroquel lowered my blood pressure so much I had to stay in the hospital 8 days.  My blood pressure hovered around 60 over 40.  I kept losing my vision
column3: falling down
column4: heard buzzing or ringing sounds
column5: slurred my speach.

column1: It was terrifying.
I had taken seroquel for a couple of years before having the acute adverse reaction.
I also became so sleepy I would sleep for two or three days at a time.

When I finally stopped taking it I lost 35lbs.  I believe that the medication has very long term effects on my brain.  I haven't taken it in three months now and I still feel foggier and more stupid than I used to be.
My memory seems to be permanently changed.  I cannot remember as well as I used to before taking this drug.
Physicians are prescribing it to large numbers of patients now.  I think there will be a large population of people who are less intelligent than they were prior to taking the drug.
Also
column2: there is no cure for hypotension.  So
column3: if you get it like I did
column4: you are just plain screwed.  Spend time considering these side effects.  I think they may be permanent.

I did have a hard time being alert on it. My dose gradually increased over time and added lamictal to it. I was taking 200mg  in the morning 200 in the afternoon and 400 at bed time. This medication worked very well however the side effects were not worth it all it made me gain weight but the problem came when I had my blood drawn and we were able to see what was going on inside  this medication raised my cholesterol messed up my sugar and my thyroid. The only good news I have after being off it for a year everything is almost back to normal. If you are taking this medication you should have blood work done on a regular basis

The only reason for one star is that if you are diabetic DO NOT TAKE THIS DRUG.  Don't get me wrong it works well but it did take some time to get used to it (out of body feeling, severe muscle twitches and cramps, feeling like I was not standing on the floor but rather floating).  Then after taking it for about a year developed HIGH cholesterol (651) and OFF THE SCALE  triglycerides (over 4600 - yes 4600 - not a mistake) in blood tests at Mayo Clinic. A soon as  I stopped taking it and all went back to normal with temporary help from chol/trig meds.  By the way docs at Mayo are not allowed to give it to diabetic patients.  But it does work for mania/manic periods.

column1: 1101$Condition: Bipolar I Disorder with Most Recent Episode Mixed$2/27/2010 3:07:31 PM$Reviewer: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $5$4$5$After months on end of little or no sleep and being hospitalized twice
column2: I was diagnosed with Bipolar disorder in January of 2010 although they had been hinting at it for a few months.  My psychiatrist finally gave me lamictal in the  morning and Seroquel  100-300 mg as needed.  I have had Severe insomnia for many yrs.  racing thoughts bad behavior and increased drinking to self medicate.  Since the seroquel  I fall asleep with ease and stay asleep and most if not all of the anxiety anger and racing thoughts are gone..  I am grateful for this medicine and even my psychiatrist teared up as she realized I was getting my life back.  while I have dealt with some weight gain I am now able to get up and move to do something about it.

column2: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Caregiver) $1$1$5$"My son was taking this.  Worse medicine I've ever seen.  I would hate going to see him

1164$Condition: Bipolar Depression$1/7/2010 12:32:40 AM$Reviewer: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $2$1$5$I have Bipolar II and from my personal experience I do NOT recommend this medication.  I was on 400mg/day for just over 2 years
column2: and was also taking 300mg/day of Lamictal.  At first the Seroquel was beneficial
column3: but after a while the side effects began to greatly outweigh the positives.  It was great for putting me to sleep
column4: and though I didn't have too much trouble waking up
column5: I did have problems feeling awake for most of the day.  It also gave me double vision for a couple of hours mid-morning
column6: which obviously made all activities difficult/dangerous.  I also experienced auditory hallucinations
column7: though not intense or alarming.  I truly only noticed them once they were absent after stopping the medication.  The withdrawl was horrible.  I was constantly sick to my stomach
column8: could barely eat
column9: and vomited for over a month.  However
column10: it was worth it!  I still experience mild hypomanic episodes
column11: but not as serious previous to the Seroquel.  I still remain on the Lamictal and it has been a savior.

column1: 1173$Condition: Bipolar Depression$1/3/2010 4:20:28 PM$Reviewer: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $2$1$3$"3 months ago
column2: I was very happy with my life and then all of a sudden
column3: I couldn't sleep at night. I started having major anxiety and feeling depressed - fear got a hold of me. Sleeping aids didn't work. I started an outpatient pysch treatment program and to my surprise was diagnosed with bipolar II. I started taking Seroquel.

column1: Now I take 600 mg a night (have been increasing the dosage for almost 2 months). Helps me sleep at night
column2: but that is the only benefit I have experienced. I feel very lethargic when I am awake
column3: and since taking the drug
column4: my mood has not returned to normal. Constipation and dizziness are other negative side effects I experience on this drug. I plan to start reducing my dosage immediately
column5: so I can eventually stop taking it altogether.  "

column1: As far as people who have a drug history being prescribed this medication

column7: this drug was very difficult to use.  Having to take it pretty much as soon as I got home
column8: to make sure that I would get enough sleep to hear the alarm in the morning.  I needed to have at least 12 hours of sleep.  It's just not possible to spend time with my husband and take care of my child on this medication.

column1: At this point

column3: it will work better for me.     "

column2: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient) $5$4$1$"I am bipolar type II; my most destructive symptom is depression. 800 mg is my dose and it works wonderfully - note that 400 mg was NOT a theraputic dose for me
column3: and it was only by overdosing one night (I was at the time very depressed) that I discovered a higher dose made me feel better. I am fully functional thanks to this medicine: attending work
column4: spending time with friends and family
column5: maintaining a healthy romantic relationship
column6: and volunteering in my community. That said: this drug is NOT for everyone
column7: and you should try drugs like Zoloft
column8: Lexapro
column9: Effexor etc before you try this drug because the side-effects can be horrible. My side effects are dry-mouth
column10: severe drowsiness and akathesia
column11: a painful panic=like attack that can cause me to walk around my apartment in circles for an hour or two after I take the drug. Luckily
column12: my doctor and I found Mirapex
column13: an anti-Parkinson's drug
column14: to stop these panic episodes from occurring. I take a significant dose of Mirapex before bed
column15: when I take Seroquel
column16: and also usually smoke a small amount of marijuana
column17: and this has allowed me to enjoy the benefits of Seroquel without the horrible panic. If you have akathesia as a side-effect
column18: and the drug is helping you
column19: please try Mirapex before you give up!

column1: Finally
column2: please note that every story in this thread is one person's personal experience - including mine! - and none of these stories are an accurate portrayal of what you will experience yourself if you try this drug. I mean this as both a warning and an encouragement; only you and your doctor can decide if this drug is right for you
column3: and I hope our stories make you more informed in this decision. God bless."

After practicing the usual sleep hygiene recommended by regular Dr which includes breathing relaxation
column3: no caffiene etc. I started with 25mg of Seroquel. I'm now up to 50 mg because i still wake up during the night frequently. My main problem with this drug is the fact that I need to take it no later than 9pm to get to sleep by 10:30 or so to be able to get up on time for work the next day. On Seroquel
column4: I need at least 9 hrs of solid sleep otherwise I feel hung over the next morning. This means no late movies or other activities with friends/boyfriend unless I take it later in the evening and cut the dose which means I probably won't sleep very well. Am also concerned that I may need to increase dose the longer I'm on it. Haven't really had any side effects other than grogginess in the morning and I don't feel safe driving after taking it.

column1: Talked to my Dr about getting off eventually & she said its unlikely as I have some mild generalized anxiety and possibly low seratonin levels (as many women over 30 do). Apparently Seroquel is not addicting like Ambien/Lunesta but I would eventually like to sleep on my own and hope its possible down the road. If you start Seroquel don't be surprised if at first it knocks you out for up to 15 hours (try it first on the weekend till you adjust)."

column1: 1360$Condition: Bipolar Depression$8/11/2009 3:50:05 PM$Reviewer: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient) $2$1$3$I've tried a lot of antidepressants over the past few years. All the drugs I've tried either didn't work or worked for a bit before they stopped working. Last week
column2: I went to my doctor to follow-up on the Pristiq I've been taking. I told her that some days it seems to help
column3: but other days it seems like I haven't been taking anything.  I also told her that a month or so ago
column4: I was feeling good so I stopped taking it for about 2 weeks and felt great before I crashed. She said it could be that the drug worked its way out of my system
column5: or it could be that I may be bipolar.  I told her that my therapist has had me tracking my moods
column6: and she thinks I may be hypomanic.  My doctor said most people call the doctor when they are feeling down and think they're depressed
column7: so a lot of the time
column8: bipolar disorder gets overlooked.  She had me fill out a questionnaire
column9: and the results showed borderline bipolar disorder. She suggested trying Seroquel. She gave me a starter pack which starts at 50mg on the first day
column10: increases to 100mg on the second day
column11: and goes up to 200mg on the third day.  My doctor said to take the Seroquel at night because it WILL make me drowsy.  I took my first dose (50mg) on Saturday night and woke up on Sunday in a major daze. My husband kept asking me if I was ok. By late afternoon/early evening
column12: I wasn't in a daze anymore. I took my second dose that night (100mg) and woke up on Monday morning again in a daze. I took the morning off work because I was afraid to drive. It almost felt like I had been drinking. That night I took the third dose (200mg). I woke up today feeling very dazed
column13: although I'm coming out of it now around 3:30. I stayed home from work today and called my doctor to see if this was a normal side effect and to ask whether it'll go away. They called me back and said the doctor is calling in a rx for Abilify instead. I hope that helps. The Seroquel has helped with my racing thoughts
column14: but I don't think the daze I've been in is worth it.

Over the past 6 years, I have gained almost 100lbs.  I went off the drug temporarily, and was able to lose 40lbs.  My bipolar disorder resurfaced, and I had to go back on Seroquel because nothing else worked.  Unfortunately, I gained the weight back.  I am very unhappy with my appearance, but am pretty much stuck on the medication.  I had to weigh out whether my mental health or my weight was more important.
1420$Condition: Manic-Depression$7/10/2009 11:26:25 PM$Reviewer: Cindy, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient) $4$4$4$I take 300 mg. of seroquel every night at bedtime. 10 yrs ago I took 2400 mg. every night and went from 120 lbs. to  230 lbs. in a year. 18 months ago I started weaning down the mg.'s and am now back to 120 lbs. and maintaining a wellness with 300mg, however, knowing my bipolar so well, sometimes I will take up to 450 mg. knowing that my manic phase is starting to kick in. If I don't take warning to my mania, I will be awake for 3 nights and four days before I completely crash and burn for 3 straight days, waking only to use the bathroom. Seroquel has, what I consider, literally saved my life. Bipolar is a life sentence, unfortunately, but I can maintain a wellness because of it.
1421$Condition: Other$7/10/2009 9:18:02 PM$Reviewer: lady, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $4$4$5$I have been taking this drug on and off for several years (usually around 75mg/night), primarily for severe anxiety (sometimes a little psychotic). I also have a history of major depression and 2 manic episodes. I do not know if these meds have an effect on my depression because that lifted 4 yrs ago and hasn't returned, and my moods are stable. I suspect that it helps because this is the longest period that I have ever been depression-free. Because of the sedating effects, I definitely feel less anxiety, and so far it has been the only medication that has helped me (I have tried many over the last 14 years). Some anxiety remains, and I still get panic attacks, so I will have to start something else as well. The drug has not been as scary as many of these reviews, but I am on a relatively low dose. Also, don't be turned off by people who complain about the initial side effects. This med takes a long time to stabilize. For the few weeks I was so tired I could barely function, but it was less every day. Now I just need a morning coffee and I'm good. If I miss a dose it is really obvious because my anxiety sky-rockets again. The only side effect of concern is extreme irritability and emotional volatility in the morning that declines as the afternoon approaches. I'll snap at my lovely husband for no reason at all, so have learned to walk away and avoid him when that happens (only about once every few weeks). It's like really bad PMS in the mornings. It's still definitely worth it.

1434$Condition: Bipolar Depression$7/1/2009 7:57:25 PM$Reviewer: Rachelle S., 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $5$5$5$I take a very small dose of Seroquel XR - just 50 mgs - a few hours before bedtime to help with sleep.  I was told this formula (the Seroquel XR) reaches peak levels approx. 4 hours after taking it and have found this to be fairly accurate.  A very important reason that my doctor has me on this drug in addition to Trazodone for slee is it also helps minimize my anxiety and mixed episodes
column2: which is a very good thing!  I was on a higher dose (200 mgs) but found it caused me too much fatigue during the day.  I have had some weight gain with this drug
column3: but that was primarily when I took more
column4: not on this smaller dose.  (The weight gain could also be related to the combination of drugs I take: Depakote XR
column5: Trazodone
column6: Pristiq
column7: Abilify
column8: Klonopin
column9: and Seroquel; so I can't just pin-point it as the Seroquel.)  I did notice that when I first started taking Seroquel it had much more of ""an impact"" at sedating me then it does now.  The smallest dose could tire me out within about half and hour.  This effect has worn out though now.  Overall
column10: I would say Seroquel is a very effective drug for me.  I know several others that take it (for varying reasons and with varying effects on their energy level) so I will say it's very important with this drug - like all prescriptions - to really find out how it will affect your sleep and energy and why it's being prescribed at the particular dose it is being prescribed.  "

column1: 1476$Condition: Bipolar Depression$6/5/2009 3:56:55 PM$Reviewer: yqjp6m
column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $5$1$5$"This medication worked for me only in treating bipolar. I had terrible side effects. First i gained 40pds. Then i was a zombie the next day and i am a 32 yr old woman with three children. It also raised my triglycerides alot. Normal is under 150 and mine was 609. High triglycerides can cause damage to your pancreatitis and can kill you. I am having a hard time remembering things and i have problems getting my sentences straight. But the worest of it all is i was diagnost with Tardive Dyskinsia which is terrible i now have movements with my mouth and tongue that i can't control. If you look up the side effects on this drug they say its suposely rare to get Tardive Dyskinsia well i guess i was that one in a millon. This drug is terrible i don't reccomend seroquel to anyone. Now on top of taking my normal biplor meds i have to take Niacin for my Triglycerides and 200 iu of vitamin e complex to help control Tardive dyskinsia. My dr told me that Tardive Dyskinsia is sometimes irriversable. Which means i will probaly have to live with it. I would not reccomend seroquel to my worest enemy. Now my dr has slowly taken me off the Serquel and put me on Geodon. Wonderful drug it gives me lots of get up and go and a different out look on life. It opens up your eyes. The only side effect with Geodon is at first its kinda like Seroquel when you get up in the morning its hard to get up an go but my dr gave me Adderall 10mg to take in the morning and i now have know problems. So to all you people out there with Bipolar with panic attacks and aniety DONT TAKE SEROQUEL IT HAS RUINED MY LIFE!!!!

1516$Condition: Bipolar I Disorder with Most Recent Episode Mixed$5/8/2009 3:09:10 PM$Reviewer: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient) $3$1$4$"I started this medication when I was first diagnosed with Bipolar Disorder 4 years ago.
I tried to make it work
column2: but I started to notice several things. First I started falling when I got out of bed. Then I could not catch myself with my arms. Then a few days later I started having tremors and my head would shake like Parkinson's. One day my boss told me he was concerned because I have forgotten things that I have done normally for years. I went to a neurologist and he said that my left side of my body was unstable.

column1: After talking with my doctor
column2: he recommended that I switch to Lamictal. Lamictal has been a life saver for me.. that is when I started to truly heal and be able to make decisions. I would say that if you are having symptoms that are worry some and scare you
column3: please talk to you counselors and therapist. You have to find the right combination when you have this disorder.

column1: thanks

Though i have recently heard that it possibly increases  risk of adult diabetes... hopefully I find it is minimal and I can continue to make progress in finding happiness in life.
Certainly the meds do not MAKE us happy
they were very difficult for me to ""swallow"" when I was first diagnosed with depression and anxiety.  I refused to think I needed to take pill to be happy.  Of course I have learned
column2: they don't create the contentment
column3: but they help us to balance our chemistry to combat the symptoms.

column1: We are all different
column2: and many times the first medications prescribed don't achieve the proper results or even worsen what you are dealing with in the first place.

column1: Dealing with depression on some level for over 15 years myself
column2: I've been through all kinds of presciptions... and just in the past couple years found a combo that is finally effective for me.

column1: So if you find the meds you are taking now aren't quite right or simply dont work... keep trying.  It will be very frustrating.
Seroquel
column2: along with Lamictal and Lexapro
column3: has helped me to better deal with my depression
column4: anxiety as well as other issues... more effectively than the many other med combination I have tried.

column1: I hope this can help at least one person out there!"

1581$Condition: Bipolar Depression$3/17/2009 3:29:00 PM$Reviewer: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient) $3$1$2$I'm now 21 years old. When I was 15 I attempted suicide for the first time, I was sent to a mental facility where they diagnosed me for Bipolar and put me on Seroquel and Lithium. I gained a lot of weight off from the Seroquel, and it messed with my head a lot. After I took it I felt extremely lethargic and sleepy. I didn't sleep well, I'd often scream in my sleep and wake myself and everyone around me. The drug made me more confused than anything else, I didn't feel as sad as I did before, but I also couldn't feel happy (unless I was over tired from taking it), it was like I was numb. Nine months later I had a second suicide attempt, I was sent to a different mental health hospital and they replaced my medications with Lexapro, Wellbutrin and Topamax (mostly to help my weight situation). I just got off all my medications last spring, so it's been almost a year now that I've been medication and therapy free. Althought Seroquel can actually treat people, I don't really recommend it for most.

column1: 1614$Condition: Bipolar Disorder in Remission$3/1/2009 7:49:48 PM$Reviewer: patient
column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient) $3$2$2$"This medication seems to have been effective at preventing another bipolar episode for me.  However
column3: I have experienced weight gain.  I had gained about 9lbs. previously while taking other meds.  Since switching to only Seroquel at 300mg a day
column4: I have gained 5lbs more.  I think that this weight gain is due mainly to the medication.  I have had difficulty losing any of the weight and keeping it off.  I have never had a problem with being anything but slim before in my life. I have also had problems with grogginess
column5: tiredness
column6: difficulty waking up from sleep
column7: and some difficulty in concentration.  My dose has just been decreased somewhat and I look forward to seeing if that eases my side effects.  It seems to be effective at helping me think positively.  As far as its effectiveness at treating regular depression apart from bipolar disorder
column8: I think it is only somewhat effective at that
column9: as I still have some symptoms of depression. The manufacturer of Seroquel
column10: ""AstraZeneca
column11: is trying to get approved for use by people suffering from depression.""  I have been on it for about a year
column12: and will think it is very effective if I have had no bipolar episodes 3 to 4 years from now.  The Wall Street Journal online has some good articles about Seroquel and its efficacy and safety.

column1:
1615$Condition: Schizophrenia$3/1/2009 6:47:23 PM$Reviewer: Zooid, 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $5$5$5$I have been on 1500 mg of Seroquel going on three years. I could not ask for a better treatment. I had an initial weight gain of about 15 pounds, which hasn't gone away. I take the full dose at bedtime. Within 45 minutes I am out and need at least 10 hours of sleep, or else I am so groggy that functioning for the day becomes difficult. About the second year in, my symptoms and minimal side effects began to recede exponentially. I haven't had problems with my blood sugar or have shown signs of diabetes. Constipation was a problem for a long time. One side effect that will not go away is that if I do not take the medication at night I cannot fall asleep and can literally be up for two days without feeling overly tired. So having a few doses in your car, at your friends houses, on you, and places of the like is important. If you miss doses there are noticeable spikes in symptoms that can last several days. Also keep drinking to a minimum. There has been a few times when I drank too much and had to stay in bed for about 15 hours before I had enough energy to crawl out of bed. There is also a very personal side effect with reduction of libido, sexual stimulation and production of semen. I had very weak orgasms paired with no ejaculation. I now have as regular bowel movements and orgasms as I ever had, with the exception that in the mornings, when the drug is still strong in my body, I cannot ejaculate. I am so grateful for this drug, it truly is a miracle. New users, know that it takes time for you to heal. Schizophrenia is a scary illness that tweaks the associations in your brain, it takes a while relearn reality by forging new synapses, Seroquel helped me rely more on facts than delusions and helps me think that my delusions are just that. If you have been on smaller doses for a while and your symptoms have receded little, ask for an increase, it will help. Rely on science and logic to identify your delusions and time and Seroquel will help them dissipate. God speed.

Dr. said I desparately needed sleep so she Rx'd this & told me to take 300mg. the 1st time & it would knock a horse out & keep me asleep about 24 hrs. & told my husband not to worry if there was no movement or he couldn't awaken b/c I really needed to sleep.  It worked just as she'd said.  Then I was to take 100mg. ea. night at bedtime.  It will make me sleepy in an hour but I can stay awake if to much anxiety.  But 200mg. will definetly make me sleep.  Problem is that w/ 100-200mg., I usually sleep 10-14 hrs.  If I can wake upp after 8 hrs., I very groggy & can't drive for business.  So I don't take it nightly as I should.  I still have sleep deprivation, but try to take it at least 2-3 times per week on days when I know that I'll be working from home.

1626$Condition: Bipolar Depression$2/18/2009 7:36:52 PM$Reviewer: NYC10021, 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient) $5$5$5$I started taking Seroquel over a year ago.  My Dr at the time put me on 200mg a day, and even though I wasn't feeling better, he kept it at that.  In the long run, he ended up up being a terrible Dr, so of course I switched.  My current Dr is awesome, and has me on Seroquel, Klonopin, and Lamictal.  I ended up spending a week in a psychiatric unit with severe anxiety and panic, about 6 months ago, before I was on my current treatment regimen.  After all of that, and during my stay in the hospital, my final dosage is at 600mg per day (50mg morning, 50mg afternoon, 500mg bedtime).  It has worked very well for me, both with my anxiety and my moods.  I haven't had a bipolar cycle in a long time, so in my opinion, Seroquel is an all-around wonder drug! :)

At first I thought it was gas which causes bloating and pressure but then I found out it was because of this medication.

column1: I honestly don’t recommend this to anyone due to the ineffectiveness of the product and because it will make you feel like a zombie for at least 99% of your day.  Before I took this medication I actually felt better so I am now at the point of lowering my own dose by cutting my pills in half each day and eventually I will stop taking this medication and seek out a naturopathic or holistic route.
I feel that doctors today will prescribe medications to patients without being totally honest about what other products are out there
column2: so we must do our own research.  I have come to the conclusion that doing your own research and finding a doctor who wholeheartedly cares about your well being and is interested and/or willing to try alternatives before giving meds that will make your life “less productive” can make the difference in solving the problem or having a medical condition that can affect you for the rest of your life.

column2: 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient) $5$5$5$I've been using Effexor 300mg & Lamictal 200mg but unable to get to sleep or stay asleep for more than 2 hrs @ a time. And my sleep cycle is backwards - awake all night and sleep all day. These meds have been wonderful but my continuing depression had escalated sleep disorders and the remaining depression from which I could not dig myself out despite the addition of a full spectrum light box I felt I needed something else if it were available.  Seroquel 50-150mg has done the trick for me for my lingering bi-polar & clinical depression.  All 3 meds + my light box have worked wonders for my 'dark night of the soul' and for my insomnia types.  Now I'm hoping to get my sleep hygiene back on track & wake up w/ a better outlook for the day. Or at least an outlook that is realistic. I'm also a Type II diabetic

column6: but my 2hr post prandial sugars are in my range of 120-135. Hope this is helpful.
