column1: 1816$Condition: Other$11/3/2008 4:33:06 PM$Reviewer: TiNK
column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient) $4$3$5$"My Opinion

column1: Seroquel good for:
Excellent Sedative
column2: Controls Emotional Instability--which is exactly what it should do.

column1: Bad:
irritability
column2: shaking
column3: withdrawal
column4: weight gain
column5: grogginess
column6: forgetfullness
column7: slight anger

column1: I've been on and off and back on Seroquel since March '08. For someone like me who was suffering from paranoia
column2: panic attacks
column3: anxiety
column4: and drasitic mood changes from being extremely happy to unbearably sad
column5: the amount of sleep I was getting was about .8 hours per night.  My first dose of 50mg knocked me out within 20min.  I have never felt better. My doctor had me gradually step up to 200mg within a week and I honestly felt better aside from the grogginess. I had no mood swings
column6: I wasn't feeling anxious
column7: and best of all
column8: my general fears subsided and I was able to gradually sleep without the light on. As a 26 year old woman
column9: I was really happy about that last one. Those were the good things.  As for the not so great things
column10: I realized that the reason I wasn't having those terrible feelings was because the Seroquel had me so tired
column11: that I didn't have the chance to be worried
column12: sad
column13: or frightend. I would wake up and just be dragging. I also noticed that I was extremely thirsty
column14: which I confused for hunger
column15: thus the weight gain of 10lbs. But I was lucky enough to catch on to the weight gain factor and control that with plenty of water. BTW
column16: it dries out your skin so if you have oily skin Seroquel is a plus! The worst side effect I've experienced is anger. Since being on this medication I become angry much easier than I used to.  In fact
column17: I never used to get very angry
column18: just sad.  Now I feel angry and irritated at small things.  I mentioned it to my doctor and told him I wanted to get off.  When I stopped taking it I experienced terrible withdrawal.  And this was only after a month of taking it.  nausea with vomiting
column20: etc. It was terrible.  I am now back on it to control my anxiety because I haven't been properly diagnosed.  "

column2: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient) $3$4$5$"on it for almost 2 years. took about a year for the seroquel ""morning hangover"" to go away. now i look at it as one the BEST sleep med. out in less than an hour.sleep the whole night through with out waking up. feel GREAT when i wake up. i did not realize how much of a sleeping problem i had. for the first time i can sleep 6-8 hours at a time. and straight through. still take it during the day. sometimes i do find it still ""knocks"" me out

column1: 1833$Condition: Other$10/25/2008 12:39:05 PM$Reviewer: feelgood
column2: 35-44 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient) $5$5$5$"Been prescribed almost every anxiety med available. Unfortunately after so long the dose has to keep increasing until you reach the highest dose. Then you repeat the process with another med to take its place. My last med was Paxil for my anxiety. So mutually my doctor and I wanted to try Seroquel. Within one week I feel wonderful other than the slight dizziness and grogginess in the morning. I am currently on 200 mg. By reading these posts that are the same situation as myself I am going to decrease my dose in half and take when I get home from work
column3: not before I go to bed to try to alleviate these 2 side effects that I am experiencing. But for ME this med is wonderful. I am completely stress free and enjoy life in a totally new light in just one week of taking this med . So something tells me Im taking too high a dose for my body to handle. I will keep experimenting until I find the right dosage. I would also like to add that everyone is different . Not every med works the same for everyone. You shouldnt ""slam"" a drug if it doesn't work for you personally. It could be a life saver to someone else and their family."

1836$Condition: Mental Disorder with Loss of Normal Personality & Reality$10/24/2008 3:09:37 PM$Reviewer: TangJie
column2: 45-54 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient) $4$4$5$I have been on this medication for about a week. My Dr. had me start with 50mg at bedtime and that first morning I could barely get out of bed. After another dose of 50mg the next day it wasn't as bad and on the 3rd night I increased it to 100mg. I was still having trouble with being sleepy for a few hours after getting up but the rest of the day was a big improvement in my mood. My wife even commeted on how I seemed to be doing better. My Dr. said I should try to work up to 200mg-300mg at bedtime so I incresed it to 150mg and the side effects didn't get any worse so I plan to go up to 200mg after a couple of more days at 150mg. I did notice that I seem to get the munchies throuogh out the day
column3: but now that I'm more aware of the weight gain problem I've been able to resist the urge to eat and so I hope to avoid that problem. The overall benefit to this drug seems to be alot more calmness in my personality and and alot less anger and homocidial thouhgts. I think it is working well for me. I would recommend starting at the low doasge and slowly increasing until you get the results you need. It does tend to make you feel hung over the next day so I started taking earlier in the evening
column4: like a couple of hours before bedtime and that seems to have resolved that problem as well.

column1: 1845$Condition: Manic-Depression$10/19/2008 3:12:28 PM$Reviewer: Anonymous
column2: 13-18 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $3$2$5$"       I have Bipolar 1 and I am 16 years old.  I was diagnosed February my freshmen year of high school and they put me on Lamictal in June.  It treated some of my symptoms in the first month: extreme interest in sex
column3: delusional thinking
column4: depression
column5: and others I can't even remember because they stopped.  But I added Seroquel last May (October now).  Stress and bad sleeping patterns set me off
column6: and I am pretty good about recognizing when I am about to go through an episode or what state I am in.

column1: I take a dose of 150 Lamictal (2x a day)
column2: 200 Seroquel (2x day).  I was a little out of shape when I started Seroquel
column3: so its side effects were strong
column4: especially dizziness (I would sit down for a long time and when I got up
column5: I lost my balance
column6: couldn’t see because my vision would go white.  And I usually fell down or smacked into a wall
column7: not fun…).  I don’t like the dizziness and this started the day after I began taking it.  Being in good physical shape can really help.   Seroquel also causes me to have episodes that I call panic attacks that started when I increased it.

column1: A trypical “panic attack”:  I have trouble thinking and functioning mentally.  I’m a vegetable.  And when I am trying to do a certain thing
column2: like math
column3: it frustrates me and then I loose it.  I start to cry
column4: my breathing gets messed up
column5: and I can’t put 2 and 2 together to save my life.  Someone will try to ask me a question and instead of answering
column6: I start crying and breathing fast
column7: my heart-rate skyrockets
column8: I repeat phrases like “I don’t know” because I can’t think and I’m completely terrified.  This is set off by stress and a change in sleeping patterns.

column1: I’m not sure if Seroquel is a good thing even though my doctor thinks it is.  But even though my doctor disagrees
column2: I can honestly pinpoint some bad things to this medication.  If it works for you
column3: great
column4: if it doesn’t
column5: we might have something in common."

column1: 1895$Condition: Additional Medications to Treat Depression$9/26/2008 4:27:08 PM$Reviewer: 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $4$4$2$This medication has been quite effective in treating my depression and anxiety. One of the side-effects was unbearable when I first started it. Excessive tiredness
column2: dizziness
column3: and forgetfulness resulted from larger doses (300-400mg). I gave up on the medicaiton at first
column4: but then I recently started to split the pills into 100 mg pieces and am taking them throughout the day. I can now handle the lower level of tiredness and I can actually stay awake and more alert
column5: although I am also occasionally left to drinking caffenated drinks to help with my energey level.  Extreme tiredness(zombie-effect) appears to be a common side-effect. To combat this I suggest trying smaller doses and taking them throughout the day instead of once a day. In the two months since being on this I have seemed to have just recently built up a bit of a tolerance
column6: thus the zombie-effect has lessened.  I have also gained 3-4 pounds  since starting this medication.  I seem to be hungry more often.  Watch out for this as well and try to start or continue exercising. I do get some other side-effects
column7: however they are minor in comparison to the ones listed above.

He was givin this drug years ago and we thought it was wonderful. Unfortunatly he was also an alcholic and they knew this when they told him to take 200mg a day. The said it would help him get his thoughts straight and enable him to stay sober. My brother died Feb. of 2007 from accidental perscription overdose. He had been drinking and taking this med. and it finally built up so much in his system that his heart stopped. He was 45 yrs. old with 2 kids. This medication may be a blessing for some but PLEASE take every precaution to monitor yourself on this. And don't drink!!!

column4: I work 2nd shift)

In a 1-2 wk. period (while in hospital) they brought her up to the full dose. (A psychiatrist at a good teaching hospital later told us the dose should have been built up to over a 3-5 month time span). When she went back to high school, she had what they call Word Loss where she would raise her hand to give her interpretation of a poem and she would have trouble expressing what she meant to say and it was very embarrassing for her. She almost got in an argument with the teacher and she is not the type to do that.
1950$Condition: Mania associated with Bipolar Disorder$8/16/2008 2:04:05 PM$Reviewer: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient) $4$3$3$A couple weeks ago, I had a manic episode with psychotic features. I was on Geodon and Lithium when it occured. At the hospital I was tapered off of the Geodon and started on the seroquel. It wasn't until I had reached the 600mg at night dosage that I was able to finally sleep eight hours. However, I do wake up often during the night. I have been on the 600 mg dose for over a week and my psychotic symptoms are finally starting to fade. Because of Seroquel, I wake up drowsy, foggy, and have a dry mouth. Also, the severe perpetual hunger caused by the seroquel has just about driven me crazy. I am determined not to gain weight on Seroquel so I am toughing out the hunger and watching what I eat for the three meals a day I do eat. So in summary, the seroquel took a little while to accomplish its task and its side effects are bothersome. I am hoping that the side effects will disapear once I become accustomed to this drug. I don't know how long that is going to take because with Geodon it took three to four months before the side effects disapeared. I don't know if I can be severely hungry for that long. 
1951$Condition: Other$8/15/2008 9:08:29 PM$Reviewer: 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $3$2$1$I have Chronic Insomnia with Bipolar Disorder and my doc has had me on and off almost every sleep aide. Sometimes I stay awake right through it, sometimes I wake up all night with dry mouth. One day I want to increase my dose to 200 and another day I want to stop taking it all together.

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient) $5$3$5$"Been off and on this med since 1999. First
column3: 200mg a night
column4: then down to 25mg a night and then up to 50mg a night
column5: I stopped it and tried to switch to Topamax---BIG mistake. Topamax made me very ill. For the last two weeks I was having severe abdominal pain
column6: which no diagnostic test could diagnose - abdominal and vaginal ultrasound. I couldn't eat. I stopped the Topamax per physician's orders
column7: and just started back on 50mg of Seroquel at night. Today was the first day in a very long time my stomach did not hurt as bad - meaning this medication works for my ANXIETY
column8: my IBS. I was wondering why I was becoming so restless and irritable during the days
column9: I think I finally figured out that Seroquel helps my anxiety and I take 50mg for sleep. I tend to be an addict
column10: so will not take Lunesta
column11: Ambien or the like. I also take Suboxone and Librium
column12: and I have been able to cut down on the Librium since starting back on Seroquel
column13: it really helps my PTSD symptoms in the morning - I was wondering why I was getting panic attacks when I woke up - - because the Seroquel had been out of my 'system' for over 2 months. The only thing I worry about is that my heart tends to beat irregular
column14: and now my physician believes I am pre - diabetic. I could lose a good 30 Lbs.
column15: but I also eat tons of veggies and ride my bike as much as possible. I do not sit and watch soap operas and eat Ding Dongs. I haven't gained much weight from Seroquel
column16: my eating sugar is to blame for my weight gain. Interesting how I had to play doctor to find out why I was feeling so horrible - I thought I had something seriously wrong with my abdominal pain. Still not sure what effect this medication has on our hearts.....

column1:
2110$Condition: Other$4/8/2008 10:41:34 AM$Reviewer: 13-18 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Caregiver) $2$1$1$My 17 y.o. daughter was on this med for nearly a year.  Dr's had maintained the benefits out weigh the side effects.  Not so in her case.  She has what we are told may be irreversible tremors.  She had severe loss of appetite and nauseau, which in turn she responded by refusing this med on many occasions.  She was admitted to a different facility and they immediately stopped Seroquel and began Risperdal-M, a disintegrating tablet and also Cogentin to combat the tremors. It is important to keep in mind that bad side effects play an important role in treating disorders, especially in teens when these side effects are visual to others and they are prone to reject meds if they associate negative experiences with treatment. Listen to your loved ones concerns regarding their treatment and know that ill side effects can outweigh the benefits.  There are other options.
2111$Condition: Other$4/8/2008 9:27:23 AM$Reviewer: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Caregiver) $1$1$1$My husband took one pill, and died that next morning from heart failure (sudden death) He was a 40 year old man, with high blood pressure. He took it to sleep.

2114$Condition: Bipolar I Disorder with Most Recent Episode Mixed$4/3/2008 4:08:32 PM$Reviewer: Janet, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient) $4$4$4$So far I have not been experiencing any delusions or paranoi that I was having prior to starting this treatment,my only real concern is weight gain which I havent had yet but I have previously had dealt with anorexia so this is of course a big problem with taking meds that list weight gain as a possible side effect.
2115$Condition: Manic-Depression$4/3/2008 10:44:41 AM$Reviewer: bent&broken, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient) $5$5$5$This is only my 3rd day using seroquel but this is the first day in many years that I have wanted to wake up.After a couple days figuring out the effects I am currently taking a 50mg at @ 11AM then another 50mg @ 9pm wich helps me sleep,although I do take 1/2 a 5mg tab of Valium before bed.I also have supplemented with the Valium in the daytime when I start stressing.I havent experienced much additional appetite or weight gain yet,I have put on about 30lbs over the winter just due to boredom while recuperating from a torn ACL.A have taken coctails of Prozac,Welbutrin, Zoloft,Trazadone,Valium,you name it,but had some very unsettling side effects from being on so many drugs.Seroquel is the first single drug that covers most of my symptoms.For today I will say it is a Godsend,for it's the first day I really felt like I wanted to live until tomorrow.
2116$Condition: Bipolar Depression$4/2/2008 3:27:40 PM$Reviewer: Nay, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $5$5$5$I was diagnosed with Bipolar II in August 2008. I had severe aggravation, anxiety, couldn't relax, insomnia, irrated easily, most of the time isolated and couldn't work to boot. I went to a psychiatric nurse practioner and she started putting me on Lamictal and klonapin for sleep. After two times trying Seroquel, the second time was the better. I think the Lamictal had to balance my mood first and my body got used to that way of functioning, more calm. My sleep is much better, can sleep through the night at 50mg at bedtime. I feel so relaxed during the day and more confident I can get through my days. Not inhaling alot to relax. No weight gain yet, but I am excercising regularly and eating right. Please don't give up on medications as Seroquel might be helpful especially with sleep. You,ll know right away with the sleep. I know we are all different and we all need different dosages or meds. but it's nice to know that Seroquel works fast for sleep and in my case three days to see the calmness. I have read so many reviews, and thank you to all who have helped me find Seroquel with yuor inspiring stories.

2139$Condition: Other$3/18/2008 8:00:28 PM$Reviewer: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient) $1$1$5$I took this drug and it turned me into a complete zombie!!! I slept for almost 24/7. I started on the starter pack (25 mgs, then 100, then 200, then finally 300 mgs) at night time. When I was awake I was a monster!!! I flipped out over anything and everything! I was in constant state of panic/anxiety and paranoid beyond belief. I had no appetite what-so-ever. A week later had gone by after starting this medication I was on the phone with my dad and I felt like I was a magnet and my entire body felt like it was going to puddle onto the floor. I got off the phone with him, called the ER and told them what was going on. They told me to tell the person who put me on the med to take me off and to find something else. My heart felt like it was going to explode. I collapsed on the bed and passed out. I woke up sometime later and found myself not being able to move, talk, nothing! I could hear my heart. It was so slow it was pausing at times. I was scared as hell. I couldn't move, but I had tears freely falling from my face. Woke up hours later, went to a counseling appt (not the nurse that gave me the med). She saw how I was and was amazed at what that med did to me. My speech was slow, it gave me amnesia (i honestly had convo's on my cell and never knew i had them!!!!) It was a horrible experience and will NEVER go back to that drug again!!!!!

I did not sleep until he put me back on it.  I was also more anxious again.  When he put me back on it mainly for sleep he told me to take 300mg and if that didn't help to take another 300mg.  This drug has helped me in many ways.  It is very sedating so I only take it at night.  I sleep very soundly, too.  My husband will come home from work at midnight and we will have a conversation.  I won't remember a word of it the next day.  This is a side effect that I am more than willing to live with, though.

column3: as Seroquel does have the tendecy to cause an excitement of the Pancreous. One can adjust to this possible deficency
column4: by the avoidance in consumtion of the amounts of sweets and or sugar one uses.

column1: This is benefit to the overall health for the person who is currently using Seroquel
column2: as excess sugars are a huge problem in our diets today as a whole. Any elimination of such excess sugars is a win/win senario with one who is currently using Seroquel.

column1: If one continues to use excessive amounts of sugars in their diets
column2: this can have the effective disabling of ones pancreatic functions by leading to Diabetic conditions
column3: which are as I noted earlier easily avoided by strictly limiting your sugar intake."

column2: 19-24 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $1$1$5$Although my psychiatrist loves this drug
column3: I found it totally ineffective. Moreover
column4: it gave me constant headaches
column5: slow (but persistent) weight gain
column6: and
column7: perhaps most importantly
column8: it made me sleep all day
column9: which rendered my totally dysfunctional.  I have found Abilify (surprising
column10: I know) and Zyprexa to be much better at treating the positive and negative symptoms of schizophrenia
column11: and
column12: most importantly
column13: allowing me to operate at a high level of functionality.  Given that all the anti-psychotics work differently
column14: it's worth a try
column15: but I have found Abilify and Zyprexa to be superior drugs.  In Seroquel's defense
column16: however
column17: I have heard that (for most people) the sleepiness wears off after a few weeks; it just didn't for me.  I would talk to your doctor and do some research about the other anti-psychotics (Abilify
column20: and Zyprexa) before taking Seroquel.  Lastly
column21: be careful at first b/c you will not be able to drive or operate machinery &c. &c.

column1: 2203$Condition: Manic-Depression$2/3/2008 8:47:41 PM$Reviewer: 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient) $5$4$5$"i have been taking this for 1 &1/2 years.I also take effexor.I divide my life in 2
column2: pre and after this med. My life has changed so dramatically
column3: in a good way!I can process info
column4: am not in a state of panic and self loathing
column5: and confusion.Now that my thinking has cleared up
column6: i must face the crazy things i did in the past
column7: and the troubles i have had all my life
column8: it is very difficult and sad.My illness ran my life before
column9: not me.I am grateful that i can now stand back and really think about things
column10: big or small
column11: the medicine allows me to have the luxury that""normal"" people have all the time.I am 55 and for the first time in my life i get to hear the words in songs I've heard for 50 years
column12: so simple yet a profoundly different experience
column13: as i was never able to comprehend even such basic stuff before.The ""psychotic"" stuff has slowed down too. It's great to be able to sleep every night.I tried easing up on the effexor
column14: but immediately had the constant body pains that i had all my life
column15: so the combo is what works.I no longer have  my physical
column16: emotional and mental life filled with confusion and pain.Weight gain has been the biggest problem
column19: and receding gums concern me.Also a series of skin infections on my feet continuously.I sometimes have bad heartburn
column20: but perhaps this is also due to weight gain.I am rarely sick
column21: have fewer colds or headaches than before.I cannot take the summer heat
column22: and find that sweating comes with any physical exertion at all.I am concerned about raised sugar levels
column23: I seem to crave sweets.I also am thirsty a lot.And finally
column24: the price is outrageous-$760 for one of the seoquel prescriptions. My health ins. does not pay for scripts
column25: but was the only ins.I could find that covered mental health.My health ins. is my biggest monthly expense
column26: more than house etc.It is clearly discriminatory for those of us needing meds and mental health coverage.Despite the side effects
column27: I cannot imagine living without it."

column3: which was causing negative side effects and withdrawal upon my trying to switch from it. Personally
column4: I would recommend Seroquel as an alternative to Zyprexa for anybody. The side effects are a bit similar
column5: but not nearly as acute or inhibiting. If you're considering Zyprexa for a psychiatric disorder

column7: and it doesn't impair your cognitive abilities or motivation like the older ones do. It will increase your appetite
column8: but I've found that side effect to decrease over time. The biggest problem
column9: though

I can't function while on it, since I feel so groggy and continuously tired. Half of the time, I can't even open my eyes. It does help with the sleep, otherwise I'd be up for days at a time. column2: 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient) $4$4$5$"  I've been taking this medication along with Concerta for about 6 years now for bipolar disorder and adhd. My moods swings are less severe now and I'm not as angry anymore. I'm more patient too. I do on occasion still have my ""bad days"" though. I take 100mg before bed and actually sleep whereas before I'd frequently go days without rest. Higher dosages gave me severe RLS and had me feeling cold one minute and hot the next. It also made my eyes extremely sensitive to light. On the 100mg dosage my 2 complaints are weight gain of around 30 pounds and a strange congestion of my upper sinuses that leaves me breathing through my mouth at night.If I forget to take a dose I will not sleep at all. I'm scared of the possibility of this medication causing diabetes as my father is a brittle diabetic. I eat very low fat meals
column3: little sweets and drink only diet soda which has kept my blood sugar levels normal so far. "

column1: 2329$Condition: Bipolar Disorder in Remission$11/19/2007 8:28:35 PM$Reviewer: AliveAtLast!!
column2: 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient) $5$5$5$"Following my Psychiatrist’s advice
column3: I started with a beginning dose of 25mg per day and ramped up to 600mg per day within 2 weeks.  I have currently been on 600mg for about 13 months.  I went from being a hopeless 30+ year alcoholic (apparently self medicating bi-polar II)
column4: with frequent in-patient treatments
column5: to a recovering alcoholic sober for over a year now.  I have no doubt that Seroquel saved my life.  I went from the brink of suicide to the most ""together"" I've felt in my 53 years.  The only thing different with my alcoholic treatment strategy this time was the Seroquel.  I've noticed a couple of posts saying Seroquel has some ""street value"" for drug abuse.  Hmmm....I would think that is the case only if you wanted to SLEEP on the street.  This stuff puts you in snooze mode
column6: so take it before bed.  I have noticed absolutely no surreal or “feeling high” characteristics.  It does give you hunger fits
column7: so you need to religiously follow Doctor's instructions and get regular blood work to test glucose levels
column8: cholesterol and triglycerides.  You also need to work a responsible weight maintenance program.  Not too hard to do when your head is screwed on straight like Seroquel has done for me.  My anxiety level went from an extremely high level to what I perceive as low.  The world is now a pretty good place to live.  I should note that I am also on 325mg Effexor XR (SSRI) per day (past 5 years) and have no idea if the combination has somehow given me outstanding results. All I can say is Seroquel RULES for me.  Your mileage may vary."

column1: 2330$Condition: Additional Medications to Treat Depression$11/19/2007 11:17:55 AM$Reviewer: Black Rainbow
column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient) $5$3$5$I was given Seroquel to see if it would help with bipolar depression and a sleeping disorder. I would be up all night and sleep in the day. I guess you could say I was nocturnal. I had pretty much dealt with that for years
column3: though. I was diagnosed Bipolar without the extreme manic episodes. This medicine is not bad
column4: I had no problems except sleepiness
column5: and extreme hunger. This is technically an anti-phychotic drug
column6: but popular and used quite frequently. I would suggest starting out on a very small dose
column7: say 25 mg. & work up from there. I was taking 300 mg a day
column8: but then stopped the medicine for a while
column9: and now use occasionally at night. 25 mg knocks me out now. You do get used to it in higher doses if you up your mgs slowly and take it everyday. But
column10: beware of the side effect of hunger because if it's not nailed down YOU WILL EAT IT! (oh
column11: but not so bad in small doses)

My wife reported this to the doctor who was sure that this would abate after I used seroquel for a period of time. column1: 2390$Condition: Other$10/17/2007 11:33:08 AM$Reviewer: infp76
column2: 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $5$5$5$"I use this for chronic insomnia at 100mg and have been on it about 3 years. I started at 50mg but needed a dose increase after about 1.5 years. I've noticed that 100mg still puts me to sleep but doesn't give me that ""whoa"" feeling when it kicks in like it used to
column3: and also takes longer to kick in. But it still works for me when nothing else has. I tried ambien at 10mg but it took 50mg (over the course of a few hours) to barely put me to sleep for 4 hours. I also tried trazedone which had the opposite effect
column4: and some samples of Lunesta which were too weak. Given all this I'm not even going to bother with Rozerem. NOTHING puts me to sleep and keeps me asleep like Seroquel. It has been a lifesaver. I've gained a little weight but that's because when the drowsy kicks in
column5: hunger kicks in as well (side effect). But I'm just lazy and give in to the hunger without considering other options to curb the hunger
column6: or consuming less fattening foods before sleep.

column1: Note to people reading this for insomnia! Most general practitioners have little/no experience with this drug
column2: and won't feel at all comfortable prescribing it for insomnia (let alone what it's intended for). You will most likely need to see a psychiatrist for a Rx. To a psychiatrist
column3: this drug at a low dose (~100mg which is plenty to sleep for most people) is no big deal to them. I never heard of this when it was prescribed to me so I did some searching on google. I read some horror stories with the drug (mostly weight gain) and didn't even want to take it but when it knocked me out the first night
column4: I haven't skipped a night since. Most of the horror stories you'll find are the exception and not the rule. Talk to your psychiatrist and they will most likely confirm this."
